Unique Signatures of Population III Stars in the Global 21-cm Signal

Jordan Mirocha1, Richard H. Mebane1, Steven R. Furlanetto1, Krishma Singal2, Donald Trinh3
1Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, USA
2School of Physics, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332
3Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, USA
mirocha@astro.ucla.edu
Abstract

We investigate the effects of Population III stars on the sky-averaged 21-cm background radiation, which traces the collective emission from all sources of ultraviolet and X-ray photons before reionization is complete. While UV photons from PopIII stars can in principle shift the onset of radiative coupling of the 21-cm transition ‚Äì and potentially reionization ‚Äì to early times, we find that the remnants of PopIII stars are likely to have a more discernible impact on the 21-cm signal than PopIII stars themselves. The X-rays from such sources preferentially heat the IGM at early times, which elongates the epoch of reheating and results in a more gradual transition from an absorption signal to emission. This gradual heating gives rise to broad, asymmetric wings in the absorption signal, which stand in contrast to the relatively sharp, symmetric signals that arise in models treating PopII sources only. A stronger signature of PopIII, in which the position of the absorption minimum becomes inconsistent with PopII-only models, requires extreme star-forming events that may not be physically plausible, lending further credence to predictions of relatively high frequency absorption troughs, ŒΩmin‚àº100similar-tosubscriptùúà100\nu_{\min}\sim 100 MHz. As a result, though the trough location alone may not be enough to indicate the presence of PopIII, the asymmetric wings should arise even if only a few PopIII stars form in each halo before the transition to PopII star formation occurs, provided that the PopIII IMF is sufficiently top-heavy and at least some PopIII stars form in binaries.

keywords:
galaxies: high-redshift ‚Äì intergalactic medium ‚Äì galaxies: luminosity function, mass function ‚Äì dark ages, reionization, first stars ‚Äì diffuse radiation.

1 Introduction

The formation of the first generations of stars in the Universe has been a topic of great interest for several decades (for a recent review, see Bromm, 2013). These so-called Population III (PopIII) stars by definition form out of chemically pristine clouds, a fact which is expected to give rise to stellar initial mass functions (Bromm et¬†al., 1999; Abel et¬†al., 2002), atmospheres (Tumlinson & Shull, 2000; Bromm et¬†al., 2001; Schaerer, 2002), and chemical yields (Heger & Woosley, 2002) that are distinct from stars today. Depending on the efficiency with which such stars form in high-zùëßz dark matter halos and their longevity as a population, traces of their existence may be found in the reionization history of the intergalactic medium (IGM) (e.g., Visbal et¬†al., 2015; Miranda et¬†al., 2017), chemical abundance patterns in metal-poor stars in the Milky Way (e.g., Jeon et¬†al., 2017; Magg et¬†al., 2017), and pair-instability supernova (PISN) rates at high redshift (e.g., Whalen et¬†al., 2014). As a result, further investigation of the PopIII epoch continues not only due to a fundamental interest in the physical processes that govern star formation, but because progress in so many other areas may be inextricably linked to the lives and deaths of PopIII stars.

Observationally, PopIII stars have remained elusive. This is not surprising, given that they are expected to form in low mass (‚àº105similar-toabsentsuperscript105\sim 10^{5}-106‚ÄãM‚äôsuperscript106subscriptùëÄdirect-product10^{6}\ M_{\odot}) dark matter halos at the highest redshifts, and probably only in small numbers. There has been only one object detected at high-zùëßz with some evidence of PopIII-like stellar population (Sobral et¬†al., 2015), though more ordinary explanations remain viable (Bowler et¬†al., 2017), especially after the recent detection of [CII] (Matthee et¬†al., 2017). Similarly, while there have been a few claims of supernovae at z‚àº3similar-toùëß3z\sim 3 whose properties are consistent with pair-instability models, and thus very massive M‚â≥100‚ÄãM‚äôgreater-than-or-equivalent-toùëÄ100subscriptùëÄdirect-productM\gtrsim 100\ M_{\odot} supernova progenitors still even after reionization (Cooke et¬†al., 2012), the lack of iron in the most metal-poor nearby stars suggest somewhat less massive progenitors at high-zùëßz (Keller et¬†al., 2014).

Another way to constrain PopIII stars is to compare the ionizing photon density of known sources relative to that needed to maintain an ionized IGM at z‚â≥6greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß6z\gtrsim 6, and/or œÑesubscriptùúèùëí\tau_{e} values consistent with Planck‚Äôs latest measurements (e.g., Visbal et¬†al., 2015). If there is a deficit in the measured photon density relative to what is needed, one might invoke new, as-yet-unseen sources of UV photons at high redshift to close the gap. An analogous but more general argument can be made using the global 21-cm signal (Madau et¬†al., 1997; Shaver et¬†al., 1999; Furlanetto, 2006), since the global 21-cm signal is sensitive to the volume-averaged ionized fraction as well as the thermal history of the IGM and Ly-‚ÄãŒ±Ly-ùõº\text{Ly-}\alpha production histories of galaxies. This was the motivation of Mirocha et¬†al. (2017), who established a set of global 21-cm predictions calibrated to measurements of the high-zùëßz galaxy luminosity function, and included only ‚Äúnormal‚Äù star-forming galaxies in the model. If these models were to be ruled out observationally, it might indicate the presence of unaccounted for source populations like PopIII stars and their remnants.

The ‚Äúdeficit elimination‚Äù approach outlined above could provide suggestive evidence of new sources of radiation at high-zùëßz. However, apparent deficits can vanish if, for example, we simply do not understand the production and/or escape of photons from normal high-zùëßz galaxies. Ideally, new sources would provide some unique signature, other than simply adding to the tally of UV and X-ray photons present at z‚â≥6greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß6z\gtrsim 6.

The zeroth order expectation is of course that the addition of new source populations will boost the luminosity density relative to the ‚ÄúPopII-only‚Äù predictions of Mirocha et¬†al. (2017), and thus raise the IGM temperature, ionized fraction, and/or mean Ly-‚ÄãŒ±Ly-ùõº\text{Ly-}\alpha background intensity. However, because the star formation rate density (SFRD) of PopIII stars should be qualitatively different than the SFRD of PopII stars (e.g., Trenti & Stiavelli, 2009; Xu et¬†al., 2016; Mebane et¬†al., submitted), the boost in luminosity density is likely redshift dependent. If strong enough, such a zùëßz-dependent boost will then manifest as a frequency-dependent modulation of the global 21-cm signal. Our goal in this work is to determine under what circumstances such a modulation can arise, and to determine whether such a signature could be unambiguously associated with PopIII sources (as opposed to, say, uncertainties in the properties of known galaxy populations).

There is certainly no shortage of predictions for the PopIII SFRD in the literature, any one of which we could simply ‚Äúplug-in‚Äù to our 21-cm modeling code. However, if we were to simply adopt PopIII star formation histories (SFHs) from the literature, the self-consistency of our model would likely suffer. As a result, we have devised a new toy model that can give rise to a diverse set of histories that builds naturally from our PopII-only models (Mirocha et¬†al., 2017). Such a simple model suffices here, as our goal is not to try to bring to bear new insights into the physics governing PopIII star formation, but rather to determine the set of PopIII SFHs that leave the most distinct signature in the global 21-cm signal.

This work is timely, as several ground-based experiments are currently targeting the global 21-cm signal (e.g., EDGES, BIGHORNS, SCI-HI, SARAS, LEDA; Bowman & Rogers, 2010; Sokolowski et¬†al., 2015; Voytek et¬†al., 2014; Patra et¬†al., 2015; Bernardi et¬†al., 2016), with space-based approaches in the design phase (e.g., DARE; Burns et¬†al., 2012, 2017). New limits from EDGES and SARAS 2 on the amplitude of the signal (Monsalve et¬†al., submitted; Singh et¬†al., submitted) are now at the level of many models presented in recent theoretical studies, (Cohen et¬†al., 2017; Mirocha et¬†al., 2017), and are thus being tested directly. As a result, the need to invoke new sources may arise sooner rather than later, if such cold reionization scenarios can be ruled out observationally.

In Section 2 we will describe our model for PopII and PopIII stars, and present their global 21-cm signatures in Section 3. We discuss our results in a broader context in Section 4 before concluding in Section 5.

2 Models

2.1 Population II Star Formation

Our model for PopII star formation is identical to that used in Mirocha et¬†al. (2017), so we only summarize here briefly, and defer the interested reader to that paper for more detail. The underlying model is very similar to others appearing in the literature in recent years (e.g., Mason et¬†al., 2015; Sun & Furlanetto, 2016).

Star formation rates in high-zùëßz galaxies are assumed to be directly proportional to the growth rates of their dark matter halos, i.e., MÀô‚àó‚àùf‚àó‚ÄãMÀôhproportional-tosubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àósubscriptùëì‚àósubscriptÀôùëÄ‚Ñé\dot{M}_{\ast}\propto f_{\ast}\dot{M}_{h}. We compute the mass growth rates of halos by assuming halos evolve at fixed number density (see, e.g., Furlanetto et¬†al., 2016), which yields results that are broadly consistent with those found in numerical simulations (e.g., McBride et¬†al., 2009). We assume the Sheth et¬†al. (2001) form of the halo mass function, which we compute using the hmf code (Murray et¬†al., 2013).

We assume that f‚àósubscriptùëì‚àóf_{\ast} is a double-power law,

f‚àó,ii‚Äã(Mh,z)=f‚àó,0(MhMp)Œ≥lo+(MhMp)Œ≥hisubscriptùëì‚àóiisubscriptùëÄ‚Ñéùëßsubscriptùëì‚àó0superscriptsubscriptùëÄ‚ÑésubscriptùëÄpsubscriptùõælosuperscriptsubscriptùëÄ‚ÑésubscriptùëÄpsubscriptùõæhif_{\ast,\textsc{ii}}(M_{h},z)=\frac{f_{\ast,0}}{\left(\frac{M_{h}}{M_{\mathrm{p}}}\right)^{\gamma_{\mathrm{lo}}}+\left(\frac{M_{h}}{M_{\mathrm{p}}}\right)^{\gamma_{\mathrm{hi}}}} (1)

and calibrate its parameters by fitting to the z‚àº6similar-toùëß6z\sim 6 luminosity function measurements from Bouwens et¬†al. (2015). Use of, for example, the measurements of Finkelstein et¬†al. (2015) instead results in a ‚àº10similar-toabsent10\sim 10% difference in the overall normalization of the SFE, which is not enough to qualitatively change our conclusions. Our default case assumes that this SFE is constant in time.

Finally, we note that our default PopII model adopts the bpass version 1.0 single-star models. This results in Lyman-Werner (LW) and Lyman-continuum (LyC) yields of order ‚àº2√ó104similar-toabsent2superscript104\sim 2\times 10^{4} photons per stellar baryon, much smaller than the yields expected of massive PopIII stars, of order NLW‚àºNion‚àº105similar-tosubscriptùëÅLWsubscriptùëÅionsimilar-tosuperscript105N_{\text{LW}}\sim N_{\text{ion}}\sim 10^{5} photons per baryon (Schaerer, 2002).

2.2 X-rays from PopII halos

In addition to the double power-law SFE model, the other critical assumption made in Mirocha et¬†al. (2017) was to adopt the empirical relation between X-ray luminosity and SFR (LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR) as found in Mineo et¬†al. (2012), with a metallicity-dependence motivated by recent theoretical (Fragos et¬†al., 2013) and observational (Brorby et¬†al., 2016) findings.

In the next section we will assume that PopIII X-ray emission analogously tracks the PopIII SFR, but because there is no empirically-calibrated relation, it will be useful to have a simple model to guide us. Readers already familiar with the physical arguments used to explain the LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation may skip ahead to ¬ß2.3.

As in, e.g., Mirabel et¬†al. (2011), we estimate the X-ray emission from HMXBs simply as the product of the number of systems in each galaxy, NHMXBsubscriptùëÅHMXBN_{\text{HMXB}}, and the typical luminosity of each system, ‚Ñí‚àôsubscript‚Ñí‚àô\mathcal{L}_{\bullet}, i.e.,

Many of the other factors seem reasonable, but strong arguments beyond the factor of ‚àºsimilar-to\sim few level are lacking. The combination we have chosen is largely with hindsight, knowing that the canonical normalization of the 0.5-8 keV LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation is cX‚àº2.6√ó1039‚Äãerg‚Äãs‚àí1‚Äã(M‚äô/yr)‚àí1similar-tosubscriptùëêùëã2.6superscript1039ergsuperscripts1superscriptsubscriptùëÄdirect-productyr1c_{X}\sim 2.6\times 10^{39}\text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ (M_{\odot}/\text{yr})^{-1}, which the product of Equations 3 and 4 roughly yield.

This is a very simple argument, resulting in an equation with many highly uncertain factors. In reality, for example, there is a distribution of luminosities among HMXBs. Though the slope of this distribution function can be explained by fairly simple arguments (Mineo et¬†al., 2012; Postnov, 2003), there are still many complex aspects of the HMXB population that we have completely neglected. For example, we have effectively assumed that all systems (when ‚Äúon‚Äù) reside in the high-soft state (HSS) given our choice of MCD spectrum with no high-energy tail, though of course many known systems are in the low-hard state. The relative amount of time spent in each ‚Äì and why systems transition from one state to the other ‚Äì are active areas of research (for a recent review, see, e.g., Belloni, 2010), and we have made no attempt to model these factors. This choice, of pure MCD over a SIMPL spectrum, has little effect on the thermal history (Mirocha, 2014), but may be an important distinction if concerned with the z=0ùëß0z=0 unresolved X-ray background (see Section 3.3).

Nonetheless, because the preceding arguments seem to work reasonably well, we employ them again for PopIII star formation in ¬ß2.4. The key point is that if the PopIII IMF is very top-heavy, f‚àô‚â´10‚àí3much-greater-thansubscriptùëì‚àôsuperscript103f_{\bullet}\gg 10^{-3}, the PopIII LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}/SFR ratio may be larger than that of PopII sources by up to a factor of ‚àº103similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{3}.

2.3 Population III Star Formation

Even upon changes to the stellar metallicity, ZùëçZ, normalization and ZùëçZ-dependence of the LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation, neutral gas contents of galaxies, and evolution of the SFE, Mirocha et¬†al. (2017) found that a deep (Œ¥‚ÄãTb‚â≤‚àí150less-than-or-similar-toùõøsubscriptùëáùëè150\delta T_{b}\lesssim-150 mK) and late (ŒΩ‚â≥100greater-than-or-equivalent-toùúà100\nu\gtrsim 100 MHz) absorption feature in the global 21-cm signal persisted. This is due to the decline in the SFE in low-mass halos (implied by the LF faint-end slope), which causes the SFRD to also be a steep function of redshift, confining the bulk of UV and X-ray photon production to relatively late times (z‚â≤12less-than-or-similar-toùëß12z\lesssim 12). The only exception is if there is a floor in the SFE (steepening in LF faint-end slope), especially if Tmin‚â™104much-less-thansubscriptùëáminsuperscript104T_{\text{min}}\ll 10^{4} K, which can drive the absorption trough to lower frequencies.

However, in Mirocha et¬†al. (2017), we assumed that the Tvir<104subscriptùëávirsuperscript104T_{\text{vir}}<10^{4} K halos either shared the same properties as the atomic-cooling halos, or did not host star formation at all, both of which are unlikely to be true. Our new models treat these low-mass potentially-PopIII-hosting halos in a simple but physically motivated way that allows their properties to differ from their more massive descendants.

A minimally-descriptive model of PopIII star formation must explicitly model (or make assumptions about):

  1. 1.

    The minimum mass of PopIII star-forming halos, MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min}.

  2. 2.

    The star formation history in individual halos during their PopIII phase.

  3. 3.

    The PopIII stellar initial mass function and atmospheric properties.

  4. 4.

    The condition which, if met, results in a transition from PopIII to PopII star formation.

All items in this list are coupled, since the minimum mass of PopIII star-forming halos is set by the strength of the LW background (Haiman et¬†al., 1997), which depends on the population-integrated LW emissivity of PopIII halos, which depends on MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} and the SFHs of PopIII halos, and so on.

In the following sub-sections we describe these four components in more detail.

2.3.1 The Minimum Mass

We begin all calculations at zi=60subscriptùëßùëñ60z_{i}=60, and take Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} to be the mass corresponding to halos with virial temperatures of 500 K (Tegmark et¬†al., 1997). The supersonic velocity offset between dark matter and baryons after recombination (Tseliakhovich & Hirata, 2010) can modify this initial mass, and thus in principle delay the onset of first-star formation and affect the 21-cm background (McQuinn & O‚ÄôLeary, 2012; Fialkov et¬†al., 2012). We will neglect this effect in the present work, as it seems to be relatively minor, at least for the global 21-cm signal (Fialkov et¬†al., 2014).

Once PopIII stars begin forming, they generate a diffuse LW background (with mean intensity JLWsubscriptùêΩLWJ_{\text{LW}}) that can in principle globally regulate star formation by raising the minimum mass threshold (Haiman et¬†al., 1997). To include this effect, we assume the Mmin‚Äã(JLW)subscriptùëÄsubscriptùêΩLWM_{\min}(J_{\text{LW}}) relation of Visbal et¬†al. (2014) (their Equation 4), and solve iteratively for Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and JLWsubscriptùêΩLWJ_{\text{LW}}, requiring that the PopIII SFRD has converged to a relative accuracy of better than 5% at all redshifts before computing the global 21-cm signal. Typically, only ‚àº5similar-toabsent5\sim 5-10 iterations are required in order to reach convergence333Scenarios with very efficient PopIII star formation can drive rapid evolution in MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min}, which can lead to the need for many iterations (‚àºsimilar-to\sim dozens) to reach convergence. To reduce computational time, we have found that simply averaging subsequent solutions for MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} every ‚àº5similar-toabsent5\sim 5 iterations damps out sharp features that arise in MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} solutions under these circumstances.. An example Mmin‚Äã(z)subscriptùëÄùëßM_{\min}(z) curve is shown in green in Figure 1, along with relationships between halo age and binding energy, to be discussed further in the ¬ß2.3.4.

But first, because the detailed properties of PopIII stars govern the strength of the diffuse LW background and thus MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min}, we focus on them next in ¬ß2.3.2.

2.3.2 PopIII Star Formation Histories

We assume that each PopIII star-forming halo has a single star-forming region (e.g., O‚ÄôShea & Norman, 2007). We assume also that each episode of star formation produces the same mass in PopIII stars on average, which will write as the product of the typical number of stars and their characteristic mass, N‚àó,iii‚ÄãM‚àó,iiisubscriptùëÅ‚àóiiisubscriptùëÄ‚àóiiiN_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}M_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}, to build intuition in what follows. Given a typical lifetime of œÑiiisubscriptùúèiii\tau_{\textsc{iii}} and a ‚Äúrecovery time‚Äù between star-forming episodes444Note that numerical simulations suggest that the recovery time could be as short as 10-20 Myr (e.g., O‚ÄôShea et¬†al., 2005), or as long as a Hubble time, depending on PopIII stellar mass (Jeon et¬†al., 2014), which would drive MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} to values lower than ‚àº10‚àí5‚ÄãM‚äô‚Äãyr‚àí1similar-toabsentsuperscript105subscriptùëÄdirect-productsuperscriptyr1\sim 10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. However PopIII stars may also form in larger numbers with a spectrum of masses. If PopIII stars are massive (M‚àó,iii‚àº 100‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-tosubscriptùëÄ‚àóiii100subscriptùëÄdirect-productM_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\sim\ 100M_{\odot}) and form in isolation (N‚àó,iii=1subscriptùëÅ‚àóiii1N_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=1), with a typical lifetime of order œÑiii‚àº5similar-tosubscriptùúèiii5\tau_{\textsc{iii}}\sim 5 Myr and no recovery time (i.e., they form one after the next), then MÀô‚àó,iii=2√ó10‚àí5‚ÄãM‚äô‚Äãyr‚àí1subscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii2superscript105subscriptùëÄdirect-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=2\times 10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. Compared to PopII halos, in which MÀô‚àó,ii‚àùMh5/3‚Äã(1+z)5/2proportional-tosubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiisuperscriptsubscriptùëÄ‚Ñé53superscript1ùëß52\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{ii}}\propto M_{h}^{5/3}(1+z)^{5/2} (roughly), PopIII halos form stars much less efficiently. For example, if we define a PopIII SFE that is analogous to the PopII SFE (i.e., relative to halo growth rate) for a rough comparison, then f‚àó,iii‚àºMh‚àí1‚Äã(1+z)‚àí5/2similar-tosubscriptùëì‚àóiiisuperscriptsubscriptùëÄ‚Ñé1superscript1ùëß52f_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\sim M_{h}^{-1}(1+z)^{-5/2}. This scaling ignores the potential connection between, for example, the recovery time and mass accretion rates, but serves to illustrate the qualitative difference between the efficiency of PopII and PopIII star formation in our model. In practice, we do not choose each quantity in Equation 5 separately, but instead treat MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} itself as our main free parameter555For individual halos this SFR is ill-defined, since the ‚Äòtrue‚Äô history is a series of discrete bursts. It should be treated as a population-averaged quantity..

The assumption of a single site of star formation results in a PopIII SFRD that is proportional to the number of PopIII halos between the minimum mass, MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min}, and some maximum mass, MmaxsubscriptùëÄM_{\max}, that is determined by our transition criteria, i.e.,

œÅ.‚àó,iii=MÀô‚àó,iii‚Äã‚à´Mmin,iiiMmax,iiid‚Äãnd‚Äãm‚Äãùëëm.subscript.ùúå‚àóiiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëÄiiisubscriptùëÄiiiùëëùëõùëëùëödifferential-dùëö\accentset{\mbox{\large.}}{\rho}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\int_{M_{\min,\textsc{iii}}}^{M_{\max,\textsc{iii}}}\frac{dn}{dm}dm. (6)

Here, d‚Äãn/d‚Äãmùëëùëõùëëùëödn/dm is the mass function of dark matter halos. We assume that PopII star formation commences immediately after the PopIII epoch, i.e., Mmin,ii‚â°Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{ii}}\equiv M_{\max,\textsc{iii}}. We set Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} via simple arguments outlined in the next subsection, and shown graphically in Figure 1.

In most of our models, the total number density of PopIII star-forming halos is ‚àº1‚àí10‚ÄãcMpc‚àí3similar-toabsent110superscriptcMpc3\sim 1-10\ \mathrm{cMpc}^{-3} at the peak of PopIII star formation, which is why the PopIII SFRD generally peaks at values of order ‚àºMÀô‚àó,iii‚ÄãcMpc‚àí3similar-toabsentsubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisuperscriptcMpc3\sim\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\ \mathrm{cMpc}^{-3} (as shown in Figure 2), which we will see in detail in the next section.

2.3.3 Properties of PopIII Stars

For the bulk of this study, we assume that PopIII stars are massive, ‚àº100‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-toabsent100subscriptùëÄdirect-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} stars. We derive UV photon yields for PopIII stars from Schaerer (2002) (the time-averaged properties in his Table 4). Our reference model assumes 120‚ÄãM‚äô120subscriptùëÄdirect-product120\ M_{\odot} stars, which emit 1.4√ó10501.4superscript10501.4\times 10^{50} Hydrogen-ionizing photons per second, and 1.6√ó10501.6superscript10501.6\times 10^{50} LW photons per second averaged over their 2.52.52.5 Myr lifetime. For stars more massive than 60‚ÄãM‚äô60subscriptùëÄdirect-product60\ M_{\odot}, lifetime-integrated yields change by only ‚àº10similar-toabsent10\sim 10%, since the lower mass stars are less luminous but also live longer. It is these lifetime-integrated values for LyC and LW photon production, commonly denoted with NionsubscriptùëÅionN_{\text{ion}} and NLWsubscriptùëÅLWN_{\text{LW}}, respectively, that we use to convert star formation rates to LyC and LW photon production rates throughout.

2.3.4 Transition to PopII Star Formation

We assume that PopIII stars continue to form at rate MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} until some set of criteria are met that trigger the transition from PopIII to PopII star formation. In numerical simulations, a critical metallicity (Zc‚àº10‚àí3.5similar-tosubscriptùëçùëêsuperscript103.5Z_{c}\sim 10^{-3.5} Bromm & Loeb, 2003), determines whether a cell forms PopII or PopIII stars. However, because our calculations have no spatial information, we cannot impose the transition based on local gas conditions (we only have global halo properties at our disposal). Mebane et¬†al. (submitted) find that use of the mean halo metallicity, in lieu of any local metallicity information, can result in PopIII SFHs that resemble those of more sophisticated calculations. We adopt a simpler approach in this work.

We introduce two parameters that aim to bound cases in which the transition to PopIII is triggered either (i) once halos have generated a sufficient metal mass, and/or (ii) are sufficiently massive that metals produced in supernovae remain gravitationally bound to the halo. The first case is obtained by assuming halos form PopIII stars for a given amount of time, ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c}, which in our framework is equivalent to assuming the PopIII phase always results in the same mass in stars or metals (since we assume a constant PopIII SFR in individual halos). The second limit is obtained by assuming PopIII halos transition to PopII star formation once their binding energy exceeds some critical value, ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}.

Large values of ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} represent cases in which the supernovae of the first stars are so energetic that material in halos with ‚Ñ∞<‚Ñ∞c‚Ñ∞subscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}<\mathcal{E}_{c} would become completely unbound. Smaller values of ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} represent cases of less energetic supernovae, which even relatively small halos can sustain. In reality, there is likely a link between ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}, since the supernovae that produce the most metals are also probably the most energetic. In other words, halos with and without PISN may still have comparable PopIII SFHs, since efficient metal production in PISN may be counteracted by efficient metal expulsion. We make no attempt to model this in detail, though such cases do lie within our model grid (see ¬ß3.2.2).

Model halo mass growth histories are shown in Figure 1 for halos that cross the minimum mass threshold at different times, with lines of constant halo virial temperature, binding energy, and age indicated for reference. The minimum mass curve in this figure is set assuming ùíØc=2.5subscriptùíØùëê2.5\mathcal{T}_{c}=2.5 Myr, ‚Ñ∞c=1051subscript‚Ñ∞ùëêsuperscript1051\mathcal{E}_{c}=10^{51} erg, and MÀô‚àó,iii=10‚àí5‚ÄãM‚äô‚Äãyr‚àí1subscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisuperscript105subscriptùëÄdirect-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. Note that the trajectory of a halo forming at z‚àº10similar-toùëß10z\sim 10 in this model is roughly parallel to the minimum mass curve (due to the decline in halo accretion rates), meaning there will be no new PopIII halos at z‚â≤10less-than-or-similar-toùëß10z\lesssim 10.

When operating in isolation, each transition mechanism produces qualitatively similar PopIII SFRDs, as shown in the left and center columns of Figure 2. Both lead to rising SFRDs at early times, which eventually peak (or plateau) before tending to zero at late times (in most cases). The most noticeable difference between the ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c}-limited (left) and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited (middle) models is that the latter can produce very sharp PopIII SFRDs which rise and fall rapidly at early times. Note that similar histories can also occur if MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} rises above the atomic-cooling threshold at early times (if, e.g., PopII star formation is very efficient and generates a strong LW background; Mebane et¬†al., submitted), enabling the formation of metal-free stellar populations with a normal IMF. Such stars are still technically PopIII, though for our purposes, and in Mebane et¬†al. (submitted), it is appropriate to count such halos in the PopII SFRD since it is the most massive stars (and their remnants) to which the global 21-cm signal and PISN rates are most sensitive. We will revisit this point in ¬ß3.1, as such histories have a particularly distinct impact on the global 21-cm signal.

If ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} are both non-zero, they can combine to produce multi-component SFRDs, the features of which are often sharp given the simplicity of our model (right column of Figure 2). Though likely unrealistic, we make no effort to smooth out such features as they make it easy to visually identify when the PopIII SFRD is governed by ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} or ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}, both in the SFRD itself, as well as the global 21-cm signal (see ¬ß3). If the values are just right, the SFRDs can be smooth, and sometimes very nearly flat.

These results are subject to the assumed production efficiency of LW photons, NLWsubscriptùëÅLWN_{\text{LW}}, which our default ‚Äúmassive PopIII‚Äù case assumes is NLW‚àº105similar-tosubscriptùëÅLWsuperscript105N_{\text{LW}}\sim 10^{5}, as is expected to be the case for ‚àº100‚ÄãM‚äôsimilar-toabsent100subscriptùëÄdirect-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} metal-free stars Schaerer (2002). The middle and bottom rows of Figure 2 change NLWsubscriptùëÅLWN_{\text{LW}} and thus the strength of LW feedback. If LW emission from PopIII stars is reduced, by assuming their properties are comparable to metal-poor stars with a Salpeter IMF (‚Äúnormal IMF‚Äù), PopIII stars can form in lower mass halos, and boost the overall SFRD. In the extreme limit of no PopIII LW emission, PopIII star formation is regulated by the PopII-generated LW background, and can result in strong, very flat PopIII SFHs.

This differences between ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} models can be better understood by referring back to Figure 1. For ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c}-limited models, the MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} and MmaxsubscriptùëÄM_{\max} curves are quasi-parallel, since the mass range depends on the growth history of halos (i.e., Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} at zùëßz sets Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} at z‚Ä≤<zsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤ùëßz^{\prime}<z). The same is not true of the ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited models, whose Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} contours can be drawn without reference to the growth of individual halos. As a result, the interface between Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} can be sharp (the binding energy is only linear in redshift, while MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} is typically steeper), and PopIII SFRDs can rapidly decline to zero as Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} overtakes Mmax,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}}. In other words, there comes a point for ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited models in which all halos suddenly satisfy the transition criterion, ‚Ñ∞‚â•‚Ñ∞c‚Ñ∞subscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}\geq\mathcal{E}_{c}, which means they immediately commence PopII star formation, even if they have yet to form PopIII stars. Note that in this case, if the critical ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} curve is comparable to the atomic cooling threshold, the stars formed could follow a normal IMF despite still being metal free.

In the ‚Ñ∞c=0subscript‚Ñ∞ùëê0\mathcal{E}_{c}=0 limit, such sharp SFRDs never occur. PopIII star formation will continue globally at some non-zero level until the minimum mass is growing more rapidly than a halo of the minimum mass. In other words, some halos will be growing too slowly to ever ‚Äòcatch up‚Äô with Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and will never be able to form stars at all. In our models, this typically occurs at z‚â≤10less-than-or-similar-toùëß10z\lesssim 10 (see Figure 1, in which a halo forming at z=10ùëß10z=10 grows at the same rate as Mmin,iiisubscriptùëÄiiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}}). As in Mebane et¬†al. (submitted), this is what ultimately drives PopIII stars to extinction in most models.

2.4 X-rays from PopIII halos

We also assume that halos hosting PopIII stars emit X-rays. In general, the emission could come from inverse Compton scattering in supernova remnants, or from bremmstrahlung as ISM gas cools. As our reference case, we assume that some fraction of PopIII stars will form in binaries, and ultimately produce an X-ray binary system, which renders our PopIII model completely analogous to the PopII model (see ¬ß2.2), except for its susceptibility to global LW feedback, and finite lifetime imposed by ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}.

As a result, for PopIII halos we introduce a scaling factor for the PopIII LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation, fX,iiisubscriptùëìùëãiiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}, defined relative to the canonical PopII LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation, i.e.,

LX,iii=fX,iii√ó2.6√ó1039‚Äãerg‚Äãs‚àí1‚Äã(M‚äô/yr)‚àí1subscriptùêøùëãiiisubscriptùëìùëãiii2.6superscript1039ergsuperscripts1superscriptsubscriptùëÄdirect-productyr1L_{X,\textsc{iii}}=f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\times 2.6\times 10^{39}\ \text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ (M_{\odot}/\text{yr})^{-1} (7)

Whereas the local (PopII) LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation, probably does not grow by more than a factor of ‚àº10similar-toabsent10\sim 10 as metallicity decreases, Equations 3 and 4 tell us that PopIII sources may be ‚àº103similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{3} times more efficient at producing X-rays per unit stellar mass formed, if indeed their IMF is top-heavy (i.e., f‚àô‚â´10‚àí3much-greater-thansubscriptùëì‚àôsuperscript103f_{\bullet}\gg 10^{-3}).

Though the typical remnant mass may be larger for PopIII HMXBs, and thus reduce the value of f0.5‚àí8subscriptùëì0.58f_{0.5-8} and perhaps also œÑùúè\tau, these are likely fairly modest, factor of ‚àºsimilar-to\sim few, effects. As a result, it is not difficult to imagine a scenario in which PopIII sources are substantially more efficient at producing X-rays than PopII halos, so long is f‚àôsubscriptùëì‚àôf_{\bullet} is large. If indeed fX,iii>1subscriptùëìùëãiii1f_{X,\textsc{iii}}>1, the X-ray background will remain dominated by PopIII even after the total SFRD becomes dominated by PopII sources, the latter of which typically occurs at 15‚â≤z‚â≤30less-than-or-similar-to15ùëßless-than-or-similar-to3015\lesssim z\lesssim 30 (see upper right corner of Figure 2).

Note that we will not explicitly model the binary fraction or PopIII IMF, since fX,iiisubscriptùëìùëãiiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} is also degenerate with MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}. We will thus attempt to qualify expectations for constraining fX,iiisubscriptùëìùëãiiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} and MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} accordingly throughout.

For the rest of this paper we assume that the minimum mass is set only by JLWsubscriptùêΩLWJ_{\text{LW}}, though in principle MminsubscriptùëÄM_{\min} could depend on the X-ray background as well, since X-rays can boost the electron fraction and thus catalyze H2subscriptùêª2H_{2} formation in dense clouds (e.g., Machacek et¬†al., 2003; Glover, 2016; Ricotti, 2016). We will revisit this potential complication in Section 4.

2.5 Generating the Global 21-cm Signal

All calculations were conducted with the ares¬†code666https://bitbucket.org/mirochaj/ares; v0.4. ares¬†treats the IGM as a two-phase medium, tracking separately the growth in the volume filling factor of ionized gas and the mean temperature and ionization state of gas in the ‚Äúbulk‚Äù IGM beyond. That is, ares¬†does not generate a three-dimensional realization of the 21-cm field using, e.g., semi-numeric techniques (Mesinger et¬†al., 2011). For a more detailed description of how ares¬†solves for the ionization and thermal histories, see Section 2 of Mirocha (2014).

ares¬†outsources a few important calculations to well-established software packages. For example, we generate initial conditions for the state of the high-zùëßz IGM using the CosmoRec code (Chluba & Thomas, 2011), and halo mass functions using the hmf-calc code (Murray et¬†al., 2013), which itself depends on the Code for Anisotropies in the Microwave Background (camb; Lewis et¬†al., 2000).

A few additional notes are warranted regarding various atomic physics calculations that occur within ares.

We compute the rate of collisional excitation/de-excitation of the hyperfine states using the tabulated values in Zygelman (2005) and take the radiative coupling coefficient (Wouthuysen, 1952; Field, 1958) to be xŒ±=1.81√ó1011‚ÄãJ^Œ±‚ÄãSŒ±/(1+z)subscriptùë•ùõº1.81superscript1011subscript^ùêΩùõºsubscriptùëÜùõº1ùëßx_{\alpha}=1.81\times 10^{11}\widehat{J}_{\alpha}S_{\alpha}/(1+z), where SŒ±subscriptùëÜùõºS_{\alpha} is a factor of order unity that accounts for line profile effects (Chen & Miralda-Escud√©, 2004; Furlanetto & Pritchard, 2006; Chuzhoy et¬†al., 2006; Hirata, 2006), and J^Œ±subscript^ùêΩùõº\widehat{J}_{\alpha} is the intensity of the Ly-‚ÄãŒ±Ly-ùõº\text{Ly-}\alpha background in units of s‚àí1‚Äãcm‚àí2‚ÄãHz‚àí1‚Äãsr‚àí1superscripts1superscriptcm2superscriptHz1superscriptsr1\text{s}^{-1}\ \text{cm}^{-2}\ \mathrm{Hz}^{-1}\ \text{sr}^{-1}. We adopt the formulae from Furlanetto & Pritchard (2006) to compute SŒ±subscriptùëÜùõºS_{\alpha}.

In addition, we follow Pritchard & Furlanetto (2006) in computing the fraction of Ly-‚ÄãnLy-ùëõ\text{Ly-}n photons that cascade through the Ly-‚ÄãŒ±Ly-ùõº\text{Ly-}\alpha resonance, and use the lookup tables of Furlanetto & Johnson Stoever (2010) to determine the fraction of energy that photo-electrons deposit as heat, further ionization, and excitation in the gas. We use the fits of Verner & Ferland (1996) for bound-free absorption cross-sections, and adopt the formulae for recombination and cooling rate coefficients from the appendices of Fukugita & Kawasaki (1994).

We adopt Planck cosmological parameters (Planck Collaboration et¬†al., 2015) throughout.

3 Results

In this section, we focus on how PopIII stars affect the global 21-cm signal. First, we explore a small set of realizations to build some intuition (¬ß3.1). Then, we move on to an expanded grid of models, and attempt to determine if the PopIII-induced modulations of the signal are generically distinct from those brought about by variations in the parameters governing PopII star formation (¬ß3.2.2). To close the section, we examine whether any of our PopIII scenarios are in tension with pre-existing measurements (¬ß3.3).

3.1 PopIII Signatures: Basic Features

In Figure 3, we show several realizations of the global 21-cm signal assuming different models for PopIII stars, but holding the PopII component of the model fixed. In each row, we assume a different PopIII SFR per halo, MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}, while each column adopts a different transition mechanism, including time (left), binding energy (middle), and a scenario in which both of these mechanisms are at work, and correlated with each other (right). The width of each semi-transparent band corresponds to a factor of 2 change in fX,iiisubscriptùëìùëãiiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}, from 25‚â§fX,iii‚â§320025subscriptùëìùëãiii320025\leq f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\leq 3200. The lower limit of 25 was chosen because it is usually the point when the trough depth first comes to be visibly affected by PopIII sources. The upper limit of 320032003200 does not correspond directly to a special case, though is about the limit of what one would expect for a source population of exclusively 100‚ÄãM‚äô100subscriptùëÄdirect-product100\ M_{\odot} stars that all form in binaries (see Eqs. 3-4). For reference, the most opaque band corresponds to 200‚â§fX,iii‚â§400200subscriptùëìùëãiii400200\leq f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\leq 400.

Each panel also shows three example PopII-only models with increasingly efficient X-ray heating. The model with the deepest trough is our reference PopII-only model (referred to as the dpl¬†model in Mirocha et¬†al., 2017), while the intermediate case assumes low metallicity star-forming regions and a strong connection between LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR and ZùëçZ (as LX‚àùZ‚àí0.6proportional-tosubscriptùêøùëãsuperscriptùëç0.6L_{X}\propto Z^{-0.6}), which boost LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}/SFR by a factor of 9. Unless there are much more efficient X-ray sources at high-zùëßz, these realizations roughly span the range of expected trough depths. The model with the weakest trough adds a new population of X-ray sources with a soft (unabsorbed) Œ±X=‚àí1.5subscriptùõºùëã1.5\alpha_{X}=-1.5 power-law spectrum that produces 0.5-8 keV photons 10 times more efficiently than our default model, i.e., with LX/SFR=2.6√ó1040‚Äãerg‚Äãs‚àí1‚Äã(M‚äô/yr)‚àí1subscriptùêøùëãSFR2.6superscript1040ergsuperscripts1superscriptsubscriptùëÄdirect-productyr1L_{X}/\mathrm{SFR}=2.6\times 10^{40}\ \text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ (M_{\odot}/\text{yr})^{-1}.

The top row of Figure 3 is most similar to the ‚Äòclassic‚Äô conception of PopIII as isolated, massive, short-lived stars, since MÀô‚àó,iii‚àº10‚àí5similar-tosubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisuperscript105\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\sim 10^{-5} corresponds to a single 100‚ÄãM‚äô100subscriptùëÄdirect-product100\ M_{\odot} star forming every 10 Myr (via Eq. 5). In this case, the frequency of the absorption minimum is hardly affected, though its amplitude can be reduced if fX,iii‚â´1much-greater-thansubscriptùëìùëãiii1f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gg 1. If the binding energy is an important factor in the transition to PopII star formation (center and right columns), the low-frequency tail of the absorption trough grows slightly, as PopIII star formation is effectively allowed to persist for longer times in very high-zùëßz halos.

At this stage, the absolute depth of the absorption trough appears not to be a powerful discriminant between PopII+PopIII models (green) and PopII-only models (gray), as considerable uncertainty (to be explored further in the next section) in PopII sources still remains. However, the depth of the trough relative to the emission peak, and the timing between extrema of the signal, appear to have more potential. For example, even as the trough becomes shallower in PopIII models, the emission maximum remains largely unchanged. Such behavior is not seen in PopII-only models, in which reductions in the trough amplitude give rise to stronger emission features. This is because heating of the IGM is driven by sources whose SFRD rises monotonically with time, whereas PopIII sources provide ‚Äúextra‚Äù heating only at early times. This decoupling of the amplitudes of the minimum and maximum leads to very broad, asymmetric absorption signals.

This general trend continues as we increase MÀô‚àó,iiisubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} in the middle and bottom rows of Figure 3. In extreme cases, a second absorption trough appears (center column, bottom two rows). Such behavior is probably unlikely, as it requires strong (MÀô‚àó,iii‚â≥10‚àí4‚ÄãM‚äô‚Äãyr‚àí1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisuperscript104subscriptùëÄdirect-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\gtrsim 10^{-4}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}) but globally short-lived (z‚â≥20greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß20z\gtrsim 20 only) PopIII star formation, so that the UV background generated by PopII sources is not strong enough to maintain the Wouthuysen-Field coupling after PopIII stars die out. In our model, this is only achieved if ùíØc‚àº0similar-tosubscriptùíØùëê0\mathcal{T}_{c}\sim 0, since halos can effectively skip the PopIII phase if their binding energy already exceeds ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c} when they cross the minimum mass threshold. Even a single, short-lived episode of PopIII star formation can prevent the emergence of a double trough777Another way for halos to skip the PopIII phase if metals expelled by neighboring halos are accreted before stars form (Smith et¬†al., 2015), though it seems unlikely that such a process could affect enough halos at early times to completely eliminate PopIII star formation globally given the generally low volume-filling fraction of metals seen in simulations (e.g., Jaacks et¬†al., 2017). (right column, bottom two rows). The binding energy alone is probably not a sufficient criterion for triggering the transition to PopII star formation, as it does not influence the cooling properties of gas in high-zùëßz halos888Except if that critical binding energy is ‚àº1051.5‚àí1052similar-toabsentsuperscript1051.5superscript1052\sim 10^{51.5}-10^{52} erg at z‚â≥30greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß30z\gtrsim 30, which are comparable to the atomic cooling threshold, though with milder redshift evolution. See the bottom panel of Figure 1.. Note that here we have assumed massive PopIII stars, so the SFR values explored from top to bottom should really be interpreted as the product MÀô‚àó,iii‚Äã(NLW/105)subscriptÀôùëÄ‚àóiiisubscriptùëÅLWsuperscript105\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}(N_{\text{LW}}/10^{5}), which implies that PopIII sources with a more normal IMF (and NLW‚àº104similar-tosubscriptùëÅLWsuperscript104N_{\text{LW}}\sim 10^{4}) will have a less dramatic effect on the 21-cm signal. We will revisit this point in ¬ß4.2.

Given the observational implications of a double trough, the likelihood of a rapid rise and fall in the PopIII SFRD warrants further discussion, which we also defer to ¬ß4.2.

3.2 Are Broad Asymmetric Troughs a Generic Feature of PopIII?

In the previous section, we showed a small set of representative PopIII SFRDs and the corresponding global 21-cm spectra for select values of ùíØcsubscriptùíØùëê\mathcal{T}_{c} and ‚Ñ∞csubscript‚Ñ∞ùëê\mathcal{E}_{c}. Our goal in the rest of the paper will be to determine if broad asymmetric troughs are a feature of PopIII models that is (i) distinguishable from PopII-only models, and (ii) expected for a broader range of PopIII models.

3.2.1 A Large Set of PopII-only Models

To determine if the presence of PopIII can be detected despite uncertainties in our understanding of PopII galaxies, we generate a superset of the Mirocha et¬†al. (2017) models (N=105ùëÅsuperscript105N=10^{5} of them) by Monte Carlo sampling the parameter space defined in Table 1 and shown graphically in Figure 4.

The bounds of this parameter space are chosen to encompass:

    The range of single-star spectral models in BPASS version 1.0 (Eldridge & Stanway, 2009) over the entire metallicity range, 0.001‚â§Z‚â§0.040.001ùëç0.040.001\leq Z\leq 0.04. Use of the version 1.0 BPASS models is to maintain consistency with the Mirocha et¬†al. We include the opacity of neutral hydrogen and helium, but neglect contributions from HeII and metals.

The basic properties of this model set are shown in Figure 4. In the left panel, we show the reference model from Mirocha et¬†al. As expected, models are roughly centered on our reference PopII-only, with ŒΩmin‚àº100similar-tosubscriptùúà100\nu_{\min}\sim 100 MHz and Œ¥‚ÄãTb‚Äã(ŒΩmin)‚àº‚àí180similar-toùõøsubscriptùëáùëèsubscriptùúà180\delta T_{b}(\nu_{\min})\sim-180 mK999Due to a bug in the calculation of SŒ±subscriptùëÜùõºS_{\alpha} in a previous version of ares, troughs in these models occur slightly (‚àºsimilar-to\sim few MHz) earlier than those in Mirocha et¬†al. Models with deeper troughs at higher frequencies than those in our reference PopII-only model have harder X-ray spectra, less efficient star formation, and/or less efficient X-ray production per unit SFR (e.g., Œ≤X‚àº0similar-tosubscriptùõΩùëã0\beta_{X}\sim 0 or small cXsubscriptùëêùëãc_{X}). Shallower and earlier troughs occur when Z‚â™Z‚äômuch-less-thanùëçsubscriptùëçdirect-productZ\ll Z_{\odot}, when the LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation depends strongly on ZùëçZ (Œ≤X‚â™0much-less-thansubscriptùõΩùëã0\beta_{X}\ll 0), and or when the intrinsic absorption in host galaxies is minimal. We find that strong neutral absorption (at the level of NH¬†i‚àº1021.5‚Äãcm‚àí2similar-tosubscriptùëÅH¬†isuperscript1021.5superscriptcm2N_{\text{H }\textsc{i}}\sim 10^{21.5}\ \mathrm{cm}^{-2}) almost exactly counteracts the more efficient heating caused by low-ZùëçZ boosts to the LXsubscriptùêøùëãL_{X}-SFR relation, and results in global 21-cm spectra consistent with the pure PopII-only model.

Our most conservative bounds on PopII models are represented by the largest black contour, with a more refined set of models bounded by the inner contour, that assumes that the SFE of PopII halos does not evolve with time, that high-zùëßz galaxies are low metallicity (0.001‚â§Z‚â§0.0030.001ùëç0.0030.001\leq Z\leq 0.003), and that low ZùëçZ is reflected both in the UV spectrum of sources and their X-ray emissions (by limiting ‚àí0.7‚â§Œ≤X‚â§‚àí0.50.7subscriptùõΩùëã0.5-0.7\leq\beta_{X}\leq-0.5, i.e., assuming the Brorby et¬†al. (2016) best-fit is correct). There are simple theoretical arguments in support of each refinement, though current measurements do not require such revisions to the model. For that reason, the inner contours are meant to indicate how progress in the coming years, e.g., better constraints on the redshift evolution of the LF and metallicities of very high-zùëßz galaxies, might feed back into the calibration of our PopII-only models and thus enhance our sensitivity to PopIII sources.

In the center panel, we focus on two new metrics of the shape of the signal. First, we introduce a measure of the asymmetry of the signal, ùíúùíú\mathcal{A}, which we define as the difference in width of the trough measured at half its maximal amplitude,

ùíú=|ŒΩ+‚àíŒΩmin|‚àí|ŒΩ‚àí‚àíŒΩmin|ùíúsuperscriptùúàsubscriptùúàsuperscriptùúàsubscriptùúà\mathcal{A}=|\nu^{+}-\nu_{\min}|-|\nu^{-}-\nu_{\min}| (8)

where ŒΩ+superscriptùúà\nu^{+} and ŒΩ‚àísuperscriptùúà\nu^{-} refer to the frequencies above and below the extremum at half its maximal amplitude, respectively, and ŒΩminsubscriptùúà\nu_{\min} is the frequency of the extremum itself. A value of ùíú=0ùíú0\mathcal{A}=0 indicates a symmetric absorption trough, at least at its half-max point, while positive (negative) values arise when the signal is skewed to higher (lower) frequencies101010We found ùíúùíú\mathcal{A} to be a relatively intuitive measure of asymmetry, though there are almost certainly other useful ways to quantify the asymmetry of the signal. We explored several, including the width asymmetry at different amplitudes, slopes at different amplitudes, and the skewness, and found no compelling reason at this time to prefer one over the other.. Our PopII-only models tend to be only mildly skewed, with ùíú‚àº0¬±5similar-toùíúplus-or-minus05\mathcal{A}\sim 0\pm 5 MHz, and a smaller tail out to ùíú‚â≤‚àí10less-than-or-similar-toùíú10\mathcal{A}\lesssim-10 MHz. The most negatively skewed realizations occur when Wouthuysen-Field coupling is strong at early times but heating occurs late or not at all.
